metadata.titleEn: Rcords of herbivore damage patterns on leaves fossil of plant assemblages in southeastern margin of the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau (2020)
metadata.description:
This dataset is derived from the paper: Deng, W. et al. (2020). Sharp changes in plant diversity and plant-herbivore interactions during the Eocene–Oligocene transition on the southeastern Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau. Global and Planetary Change, 194, 103293. doi:10.1016/j.gloplacha.2020.103293
This data contains herbivore damage patterns on fossil leaves of plant assemblages from the latest Eocene layer and the earliest Oligocene layer in Kajun Village, Markam County, southeastern margin of the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau.
Herbivore damage patterns on fossil leaves are essential to explore the evolution of plant-herbivore interactions under paleoenvironmental changes and to better understand the evolutionary history of terrestrial ecosystems. The Eocene–Oligocene transition (EOT) is a period of dramatic paleoclimate changes that significantly impacted global ecosystems, Researchers identified taxonomic composition of the flora, and investigated well-preserved herbivore damage on fossil leaves from two layers(the latest Eocene layer (MK-3, ~34.6 Ma) and the earliest Oligocene layer (MK-1, ~33.4 Ma)) of the Lawula Formation in Markam County, southeastern Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau (QTP), China.
The data contains tables of the records of the leaves fossil, the fileds of the tables are as following:
Basic Code; Database RFID; Family code; Genera code; Species code; Marks; Plant-herbivore; Leaves for damage; FFGs & DTs; Code marks; Hole feeding; Margin feeding; Skeletonization; Surface feeding; Piercing & Sucking; Oviposition; Mining; Galling; Fungal; Incertae Sedis; Boring; Undefined
This dataset also contains some figures in the article.
metadata.instructions: The table files are named MK-1 Summary and MK-3 Summary respectively, which can be viewed and edited by Excel software in Microsoft office

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of datasets that record plant-herbivore interactions through leaf fossil damage?
Feature Specification.Answer: basic code, database RFID, family code, genera code, species code, marks, plant-herbivore interactions, number of damaged leaves, insect damage types, hole feeding, margin feeding, skeletonization, surface feeding, piercing and sucking, oviposition, mining, galling, fungal, incertae sedis, boring, undefined

Definition.Question: What does 'plant-herbivore interactions' mean in the context of paleobotanical studies on fossilized leaves?
Definition.Answer: In the context of paleobotanical studies on fossilized leaves, 'plant-herbivore interactions' refer to the examination of how herbivorous animals impacted plant life, as evidenced by damage types on fossilized leaves. This involves analyzing various types of feeding and damage marks left on leaves by herbivores, which helps researchers understand the interactions between plants and herbivores during specific geological periods, such as the Eocene-Oligocene transition.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors could have influenced the different types of herbivore damage observed on plant leaf fossils during the Eocene–Oligocene transition on the southeastern Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The variations in herbivore damage types on plant leaf fossils during the Eocene–Oligocene transition could be influenced by several factors, including changes in climate conditions, shifts in herbivore diversity and abundance, and alterations in plant community composition on the southeastern Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential impacts on our understanding of plant-herbivore interactions if data collection methods were enhanced to include more detailed fossil leaf damage records from the Eocene-Oligocene transition period on the southeastern Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Enhanced data collection methods could lead to a more comprehensive understanding of the dynamics between plant and herbivore interactions during the Eocene-Oligocene transition. By including more detailed fossil leaf damage records, researchers might better identify specific herbivory patterns and their variations over time, which can shed light on the influence of climatic changes on these interactions. This could ultimately improve our understanding of historical ecosystem evolutions and contribute to models predicting future ecological responses to climate shifts.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of analyzing plant-herbivore interaction data during the Eocene-Oligocene transition on the southeastern Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to explore the development of plant-herbivore interactions under ancient environmental changes and to better understand the evolution of soil ecosystems. The Eocene-Oligocene transition was a period of significant climatic change that had a major impact on global ecosystems, and the analysis of this data helps in understanding these changes in the context of the southeastern Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to identify and document herbivory damage types on fossilized plant leaves in paleoecological studies?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In paleoecological studies, procedures to identify and document herbivory damage types on fossilized plant leaves involve examining well-preserved plant fossil leaves for signs of damage caused by herbivorous activity. Researchers classify the damage into various categories, such as hole feeding, margin feeding, skeletonization, surface feeding, piercing & sucking, oviposition, mining, galling, fungal, incertae sedis, boring, and undefined. Each type of damage is marked and recorded using a coding system to facilitate analysis of plant-herbivore interactions and understand the evolution of soil ecosystems during specific geological periods, such as the Eocene-Oligocene transition.
